node.title: When Can the Covid Masks Finally Come Off?
node.alt: Vaccinations at a community site in San Francisco this month. As cases drop and vaccine eligibility expands, some public officials began considering how to end mask mandates.
node.description: Although the end of mask mandates is in sight, restrictions should remain in place through the holidays, experts say.
node.content: ["Amid the turmoil of the last two years \u2014 a period that included a deadly pandemic, mass layoffs, an ugly presidential election and an attack on the United States Capitol \u2014 some of the fiercest political debates in America have been waged over a nearly weightless piece of fabric: the face mask.", "American officials were slow to embrace face masks as a strategy for slowing the spread of the coronavirus. When they finally did, masks became a potent symbol of the pandemic \u2014 a common-sense public health measure turned political flashpoint and a visible reminder that life was anything but normal.", "Now, with the summer\u2019s Delta surge in the rearview mirror and the vaccination of school-age children underway, many Americans are wondering when the masks might finally come off.", "\u201cThe best science does support mask-wearing as a valid strategy to reduce Covid-19,\u201d said Dr. Stephen Luby, an infectious disease expert and epidemiologist at Stanford University. \u201cThe issue is: Well, how long do we do this, and in how many contexts?\u201d He added, \u201cDo we all wear masks the rest of our lives?\u201d", "Some public officials are already mapping out an endgame. On Tuesday, Mayor Muriel Bowser of Washington, D.C., announced that indoor mask requirements would be loosened. The next day, Florida lawmakers passed a bill banning school mask mandates, which some districts had already abandoned.", "Eric Adams, New York City\u2019s mayor-elect, \u201cwants to drop the mask mandate in schools when health officials determine it\u2019s safe,\u201d his spokesman said in an email.", "That time has not yet come, experts said.", "\u201cCases are starting to rise again, and we have not yet conquered this virus,\u201d said Anne Rimoin, an epidemiologist at the University of California, Los Angeles. \u201cWe may be tired of Covid and Covid restrictions and public health measures, but this virus is certainly not done with us yet.\u201d", "The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that even fully vaccinated people wear masks in public indoor spaces where community transmission of the virus is \u201csubstantial or high.\u201d Currently, roughly 85 percent of U.S. counties meet that threshold, which is defined as at least 50 new cases weekly per 100,000 residents.", "It will be safer to ease mask requirements early next year, scientists said, after more children have been fully vaccinated and the holiday travel season has passed. And voluntary mask-wearing will continue to be helpful in certain circumstances, as well as in future cold and flu seasons, they noted.", "\u201cI don\u2019t think we\u2019re going to want to put all our masks away,\u201d Dr. Luby said.", "Several lines of evidence support the effectiveness of face masks as a public health intervention.", "Laboratory studies have shown that even basic cloth masks can block more than 50 percent of small aerosols; surgical masks and N95 respirators are even better. And real-world research suggests that statewide and schoolwide mask mandates curb the spread of the virus.", "A randomized trial, conducted by Dr. Luby and his colleagues in 600 villages in Bangladesh, demonstrated that a mask-wearing intervention, including the distribution of free masks and a multipronged messaging campaign, led to substantial increases in mask-wearing and declines in Covid cases. (The study has not yet been published in a scientific journal.)", "All of these studies have limitations, but together they, and many similar analyses, add up to a clear conclusion.", "\u201cThere is an overwhelming amount of evidence that masks help slow transmission,\u201d said Linsey Marr, an expert in airborne viruses at Virginia Tech.", "Face masks are not without drawbacks. \u201cThey impede communication,\u201d Dr. Marr said. \u201cThey can be uncomfortable.\u201d", "Some people with disabilities may not be able to wear masks, and there is still debate over how to weigh the benefits and downsides of masking young children, who are much less likely than adults to become seriously ill from the virus. (The C.D.C. says that children under 2 should not wear masks, while the World Health Organization recommends against requiring masks for children under 6.)", "But given that most people tolerate masks well and that mask-wearing is far less disruptive than other mitigation measures like lockdowns, face masks are a key tool in managing the pandemic, experts said.", "\u201cI think mask-wearing is, in many ways, one of the interventions that you probably want to relax last,\u201d said Richard Stutt, an infectious disease modeler at the University of Cambridge. \u201cMask-wearing is very, very low cost in comparison to most other interventions.\u201d", "But mask mandates were never intended to last forever, and this fall, as cases dropped and vaccine eligibility expanded, some public officials began considering how to end them.", "This month, the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health announced its criteria, including specific vaccination and transmission benchmarks, for lifting some of its indoor masking requirements.", "Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey recently said he hoped to lift the state\u2019s school mask mandate \u201csooner than later\u201d and floated the idea of eliminating the requirement in phases, beginning with high schools, whose teenage students have been eligible for vaccination for months.", "But loosening mask requirements now would be premature, experts said, especially as we head into the winter, when people spend more time indoors, holiday travel brings far-flung people together and respiratory viruses circulate easily.", "\u201cNow is not the time that I would reduce mask mandates,\u201d Dr. Luby said.", "Dr. Marr recommended not lifting school mask mandates until after the winter holidays had passed and more school-age children had had the chance to get both of their shots. If community transmission levels are low or moderate a few weeks after school resumes in January, then, \u201cYeah, let\u2019s get rid of the masks,\u201d she said.", "Seema Lakdawala, a respiratory virus expert at the University of Pittsburgh, imagined a similar timeline: \u201cMaybe in February, we can say goodbye to masks.\u201d", "Other experts were reluctant to provide a date. Dr. Rimoin said she would like to see a more sustained reduction in cases and deaths before easing mask requirements. \u201cWe\u2019re still seeing 1,000 people dying a day from this virus,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s not just a matter of comfort and ease \u2014 I mean, this is a matter of life or death for many people.\u201d", "Easing mask restrictions will need to be a local decision, scientists stressed, based on a complex set of factors including local transmission and vaccination rates, and the vulnerability of the population in question.", "\u201cIf a region or particular community is having an outbreak, then I think it would make a lot of sense for people within that community to be wearing masks even if, nationally, things are fairly under control,\u201d Dr. Stutt said.", "And mask-wearing is not all-or-nothing. Even after mandates are lifted, it will make sense for some people \u2014 older adults or those who are immunocompromised, for instance \u2014 to wear masks in certain circumstances and settings. And people should be prepared to put masks back on in the event of future surges, scientists said.", "Experts also expressed hope that new mask-wearing norms might outlast the pandemic. Face masks could help reduce transmission of other respiratory viruses, and experts said that they planned to continue wearing masks in some environments, such as on planes and buses, during future flu seasons.", "\u201cBefore the pandemic there was a stigma associated with wearing masks in this country, but I think it\u2019s become normalized in a lot of places,\u201d Dr. Marr said. (Still, she acknowledged, \u201cI think others will never wear a mask again.\u201d)", "Dr. Lakdawala expressed hope that as other pandemic restrictions eased, people might find a brief period of mask-wearing, in certain high-risk situations, less onerous.", "\u201cHopefully as people become more comfortable with vaccination and realize that they can see their friends and family and they can go and do their normal activities in a safe way, wearing a mask on a bus for the 20 minutes you need to ride it to work isn\u2019t seen as a burden,\u201d she said. \u201cIt\u2019s seen as a way to protect yourself and your family.\u201d"]
